questions.text:
A 67-year-old man with colon cancer metastatic to the liver presents to the emergency department with intractable nausea and vomiting. Three days earlier, he had started chemotherapy with infusional fluorouracil, oxaliplatin, and bevacizumab. At that time, he was prescribed oral prochlorperazine for prevention of nausea and vomiting.
In the emergency department, his blood pressure is 100/50 mm Hg and his heart rate is 120 beats per minute. He appears dehydrated. He is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative. A radiograph of the abdomen shows no evidence of bowel obstruction.
In addition to hydration, which one of the following management strategies is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Management of chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting should focus on prevention. When that fails, volume deficits and electrolyte abnormalities should be corrected, and additional antiemetics should be given, preferably from different drug classes than the ones used for prophylaxis.

In this case, the phenothiazine prochlorperazine has already failed to prevent nausea and vomiting, so this drug class should be avoided if possible. Oral agents should also be avoided because they are unlikely to be effective in a patient with active nausea and vomiting. The best option among those listed is the combination of intravenous palonosetron (a 5-hydroxytryptamine3-receptor antagonist) and intravenous dexamethasone (a glucocorticoid that has proven effective for treatment of chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting in clinical trials). Other 5-hydroxytryptamine3-receptor antagonists that may be used for chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting include granisetron and ondansetron.

Key learning point: Patients with chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting who do not respond to preventive treatment with prochlorperazine are most appropriately treated with intravenous palonosetron and dexamethasone.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral benzodiazepines, such as alprazolam, are sometimes used to treat anticipatory nausea.

C) INCORRECT:

In this case, the phenothiazine prochlorperazine has already failed to prevent nausea and vomiting, so this drug class should be avoided if possible.

D) INCORRECT:

In this case, the phenothiazine prochlorperazine has already failed to prevent nausea and vomiting, so this drug class should be avoided if possible. Oral agents should also be avoided because they are unlikely to be effective in a patient with active nausea and vomiting.

E) INCORRECT:

Aprepitant is an oral neurokinin-1–receptor antagonist that is generally used in combination with other agents for the prevention of chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting.

questions.text:
A 64-year-old man presents with weakness, fatigue, and mild shortness of breath on exertion after his second cycle of neoadjuvant cisplatin-based chemotherapy for muscle-invasive bladder cancer. He also reports some mild nausea that is relieved with antiemetics. He has no other sites of disease and has been planning to undergo definitive cystectomy with curative intent after finishing chemotherapy.
On physical examination, the patient is pale. Before he started chemotherapy, his hemoglobin level and hematocrit were within normal limits (14 g/dL and 42%, respectively), with a mean corpuscular volume of 92 μm3 (reference range, 80–100), but repeat testing shows the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
7.7
13.5–17.5


Hematocrit (%)
26
41–53


Iron (μg/dL)
122
30–160


Iron-binding capacity (μg/dL)
305
228–428


Transferrin saturation (%)
40
15–45


Ferritin (ng/mL)
84
30–300


Mean corpuscular volume (μm3)
88
80–100


Platelet count (per mm3)
104,000
150,000–350,000


Absolute neutrophil count (per mm3)
>1500
1900–7600


Which one of the following management strategies is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Folate deficiency is associated with macrocytosis; this patient’s mean corpuscular volume is normal.

B) INCORRECT:

Erythropoietin-stimulating agents, such as epoetin alfa, are approved for the treatment of chemotherapy-induced anemia in patients receiving palliative chemotherapy. Because meta-analyses have suggested that erythropoietin-stimulating agents may increase mortality in patients receiving chemotherapy or radiotherapy, the use of these agents in patients undergoing cancer treatment with curative intent is controversial.

C) CORRECT:

This patient is planning to undergo cancer treatment with curative intent and has developed symptomatic chemotherapy-induced anemia. Red-cell transfusion is the most appropriate treatment in this scenario, according to guidelines from the National Comprehensive Cancer Network and the Association for the Advancement of Blood and Biotherapies. Although there are specific hemoglobin and hematocrit thresholds for red-cell transfusion in patients with asymptomatic anemia, there are no such thresholds for those with symptomatic anemia.

Key learning point: The most appropriate management for a patient with symptomatic chemotherapy-induced anemia and normal iron studies who is undergoing curative-intent therapy for limited-stage cancer is transfusion of packed red cells.

D) INCORRECT:

In a patient with potentially curable disease, the dose of chemotherapy would be reduced only if the anemia was very severe and not manageable with other interventions.

E) INCORRECT:

Iron deficiency is an unlikely cause of this patient’s anemia, given the normal iron studies. Even if the patient was found to have iron deficiency complicating his chemotherapy-induced myelosuppression, iron supplementation would not increase his hemoglobin level and hematocrit quickly enough to reduce his symptoms and prepare him for the next round of chemotherapy.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old premenopausal woman with stage IIIC breast cancer is scheduled to begin neoadjuvant chemotherapy with four cycles of doxorubicin and cyclophosphamide followed by four cycles of docetaxel. At presentation for the first cycle of treatment, she is given ondansetron and dexamethasone and then continues to take the ondansetron every 8 hours afterward. Approximately 28 hours after treatment, she calls, noting severe nausea and three episodes of emesis during the previous 6 hours.
Which one of the following antiemetic regimens is recommended in the pretreatment setting for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Acute chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting (CINV) typically occurs within the first 24 hours after treatment, whereas delayed CINV sets in more than 24 hours after chemotherapy and may persist for several days. Risk for CINV is increased among patients receiving highly emetogenic chemotherapy regimens, those with a history of motion sickness or severe CINV, and those with high levels of anxiety. Additional risk factors include female sex and age <50 years.

The most appropriate antiemetic treatment for patients receiving chemotherapy with a high risk of emesis is a combination of a 5-hydroxytryptamine type 3 receptor antagonist (such as ondansetron), a glucocorticoid (such as dexamethasone), and a neurokinin-1 inhibitor (such as aprepitant or fosaprepitant).

Research on neurokinin-1 inhibitors suggests that preventing acute CINV effectively reduces the incidence of delayed CINV. Moreover, two phase III studies have demonstrated that a 5-hydroxytryptamine type 3 receptor antagonist alone does not provide optimal protection against delayed CINV, and additional agents, including a glucocorticoid and a neurokinin-1 inhibitor, should be added to increase the response in the delayed phase.

Key learning point: The most appropriate antiemetic treatment for patients receiving chemotherapy with a high risk of emesis is a combination of 5-hydroxytryptamine type 3 receptor antagonist, a glucocorticoid, and a neurokinin-1 inhibitor.

B) INCORRECT:

The most appropriate antiemetic treatment for patients receiving chemotherapy with a high risk of emesis is a combination of a 5-hydroxytryptamine type 3 receptor antagonist (such as ondansetron), a glucocorticoid (such as dexamethasone), and a neurokinin-1 inhibitor (such as aprepitant or fosaprepitant).

C) INCORRECT:

The most appropriate antiemetic treatment for patients receiving chemotherapy with a high risk of emesis is a combination of a 5-hydroxytryptamine type 3 receptor antagonist (such as ondansetron), a glucocorticoid (such as dexamethasone), and a neurokinin-1 inhibitor (such as aprepitant or fosaprepitant).

D) INCORRECT:

Metoclopramide has a low therapeutic index for treating chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting and is more likely to cause adverse effects than agents that have a higher therapeutic index. Antianxiety agents, such as lorazepam, have only modest antiemetic efficacy, although they may help in the prevention and treatment of anticipatory emesis.

E) INCORRECT:

Metoclopramide has a low therapeutic index for treating chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting and is more likely to cause adverse effects than agents that have a higher therapeutic index. The most appropriate antiemetic treatment for patients receiving chemotherapy with a high risk of emesis is a combination of a 5-hydroxytryptamine type 3 receptor antagonist (such as ondansetron), a glucocorticoid (such as dexamethasone), and a neurokinin-1 inhibitor (such as aprepitant or fosaprepitant).

questions.text:
A 74-year-old man presents to the emergency department reporting a 2-week history of weakness, dehydration, and profuse diarrhea. He has 10 bowel movements daily that he describes as loose, watery, and nonbloody. He has mild abdominal pain but no fevers, nausea, or vomiting. His medical history is significant for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, hypertension, gout, and recently diagnosed metastatic, unresectable melanoma that has been treated with ipilimumab (a cytotoxic T-lymphocyte antigen-4 inhibitor) for the past 7 weeks. He reports no recent sick contacts, no travel abroad, and no antibiotic exposure. He has not experienced any other new symptoms.
He has a temperature of 36.8°C, a heart rate of 110 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 102/55 mm Hg, and an oxygen saturation of 97% while breathing ambient air. Physical examination reveals dry mucous membranes and poor skin turgor. Cardiac and lung examinations are within normal limits. Abdominal examination reveals diffuse mild tenderness, with no guarding or rigidity.
A complete blood count and liver function tests are within normal limits. Other laboratory results are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range


Sodium (mEq/liter)
129
136–145


Potassium (mEq/liter)
3.4
3.5–5.0


Chloride (mEq/liter)
90
98–106


Bicarbonate (mEq/liter)
19
21–30


Blood urea nitrogen (mg/dL)
23
10–20


Creatinine (mg/dL)
2.4 (baseline, 1.2)
0.8–1.3


Stool studies — including culture, ova and parasite testing, and Clostridioides difficile toxin testing — are negative. CT of the abdomen and pelvis with oral contrast reveals pancolitis without perforation, strictures, fistula, or abscess formation.
A colonoscopy is performed (figure). Biopsies show mixed neutrophilic-lymphocytic infiltrates and are negative for cytomegalovirus, protozoal infections, and granulomas.
Supportive management is provided with intravenous fluids and antidiarrheal agents.
Which one of the following management strategies is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Stop ipilimumab temporarily, and start ciprofloxacin and metronidazole
Stop ipilimumab indefinitely, and start prednisone
Stop ipilimumab indefinitely, and start infliximab

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient has no indication for broad-spectrum antibiotics (e.g., ciprofloxacin and metronidazole), given that he is afebrile with a normal leukocyte count and a negative infectious workup.

B) CORRECT:

This patient is experiencing immunotherapy-induced colitis. Immunotherapy refers to a range of agents that promote an immune response against malignancies. These agents act by releasing the immune system from the mechanisms used by tumor cells to evade an immune response, such as tumor expression of a variety of molecules that modulate the immune response. Currently available classes of immunotherapy agents include cytotoxic T-lymphocyte antigen-4 (CTLA-4) inhibitors such as ipilimumab, programmed cell death receptor 1 (PD-1) inhibitors such as pembrolizumab, and programmed cell death ligand 1 (PD-L1) inhibitors such as atezolizumab and avelumab.

One of the main adverse effects of immunotherapy is that the release of immune system inhibition can lead to immunologically mediated inflammation and destruction of organs. The gastrointestinal system is frequently affected, usually in the form of colitis, which is more common with CTLA-4 inhibitors than with PD-1 inhibitors. Diarrhea, the most common symptom, usually starts within 6 weeks after treatment initiation and is usually nonbloody. Initial workup includes a thorough history and physical examination, comprehensive laboratory testing, infectious evaluation, and consideration of a CT scan and colonoscopy with biopsies. Colonic biopsies typically show a mixed neutrophilic-lymphocytic infiltrate.

The severity of diarrhea is graded according to the patient’s symptoms, and the grade then determines management.

• Grade 1: <4 episodes daily
• Grade 2: 4 to 6 episodes daily
• Grade 3: ≥7 episodes daily or requirement for inpatient hospitalization
• Grade 4: life-threatening consequences

For grade 1 disease, immunotherapy can usually be continued, and patients can be managed symptomatically.

For grade 2 disease, immunotherapy should be temporarily withheld until symptoms improve to grade 1, and glucocorticoids can be considered.

For grades 3 and 4 disease, the recommended approach is to permanently discontinue CTLA-4 inhibitors and start high-dose glucocorticoids (1–2 mg/kg/day). If the patient’s symptoms do not improve after 3 to 5 days of glucocorticoid therapy, tumor necrosis factor inhibitor therapy with infliximab should be considered. If the patient was taking a PD-1 or PD-L1 inhibitor (rather than a CTLA-4 inhibitor), that drug can be restarted after grade 3 symptoms improve to grade 1 — but should be permanently discontinued if grade 4 disease develops.

This patient has grade 3 disease (10 episodes of diarrhea daily) and should therefore stop the ipilimumab indefinitely and start high-dose glucocorticoids. He has no indication for broad-spectrum antibiotics (e.g., ciprofloxacin and metronidazole), given that he is afebrile with a normal leukocyte count and a negative infectious workup.

Key learning point: Management of grade 3 or 4 colitis induced by a cytotoxic T-lymphocyte antigen-4 (CTLA-4) inhibitor involves permanent discontinuation of the CTLA-4 inhibitor and treatment with high-dose glucocorticoids.

C) INCORRECT:

Colestipol has no role in the management of immunotherapy-induced colitis. It is used primarily for treating bile-acid-induced diarrhea.

D) INCORRECT:

For grade 1 immunotherapy-induced colitis, immunotherapy can usually be continued. However, this patient has grade 3 disease and should discontinue ipilimumab indefinitely.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient has grade 3 immunotherapy-induced colitis. Tumor necrosis factor inhibitor therapy with infliximab should be considered if the patient’s symptoms do not improve after 3 to 5 days of glucocorticoid therapy but infliximab is not a part of the initial treatment for grade 3 disease.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with metastatic lung cancer receiving pembrolizumab for the past 4 months presents with a 5-day history of progressive dyspnea and dry cough. He reports difficulty climbing stairs and with routine househodl activities, which he could do easily 2 weeks ago. Vital signs are BP, 128/82; P, 92; R, 22; T, 37.8°C (100.0°F); oxygen saturation 90% on room air. Physical examination shows bilateral fine crackles without wheezing. Chest CT shows bilateral ground-glass opacities in a peripheral distribution. Laboratory studies show a white blood cell count of 7,200/μL and C-reactive protein 45 mg/L. What is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Arrange for bronchoscopy with bronchoalveolar lavage

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Discharge is inappropriate for this patient with significant respiratory symptoms, hypoxemia, and functional impairment. The clinical presentation suggests a serious complication requiring immediate treatment and further evaluation.

B) INCORRECT:

The normal white blood cell count, minimal fever, and bilateral ground-glass pattern are not typical of bacterial pneumonia. This presentation suggests a non-infectious inflammatory process related to immune checkpoint inhibitor therapy.

C) INCORRECT:

While pulmonary embolism should be considered in cancer patients with dyspnea, the bilateral ground-glass opacities and temporal relationship to pembrolizumab therapy are more suggestive of immune checkpoint inhibitor pneumonitis than thromboembolic disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Bronchoscopy is not immediately indicated, given the clinical presentation is highly suggestive of immune checkpoint inhibitor pneumonitis. Initial management should prioritize treatment and stabilization over invasive diagnostic procedures.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- This presentation is consistent with immune checkpoint inhibitor–induced pneumonitis. Bilateral ground-glass opacities, functional impairment, and the temporal relationship to pembrolizumab support the diagnosis. Corticosteroid therapy should be initiated with concurrent oncology consultation.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with pancreatic adenocarcinoma receiving FOLFIRINOX chemotherapy presents with abdominal cramping and 12 loose stools over the past 24 hours. Vital signs are BP, 88/52; P, 118; T, 38.4°C (101.2°F). Laboratory studies show WBC count 2,100/μL, hemoglobin 9.2 g/dL, and creatinine 1.8 mg/dL (baseline 1.1 mg/dL). What is the most appropriate initial management priority?

choices.text: Obtain stool studies and C. difficile toxin test
Initiate octreotide and schedule oncology consultation
Start high-dose loperamide and observe response
Administer IV fluids and obtain blood cultures

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While stool studies are important in complicated diarrhea, they are not the immediate priority in a hemodynamically unstable patient with neutropenic fever. Acute stabilization and evaluation for life-threatening infections takes precedence.

B) INCORRECT:

Octreotide is considered for persistent diarrhea after first-line treatments have been unsuccessful and complications have been ruled out. This patient requires immediate hemodynamic stabilization and evaluation for neutropenic fever before considering specific antidiarrheal therapy.

C) INCORRECT:

Empiric antibiotics are indicated for neutropenic fever, but blood cultures must be obtained first when possible. Furthermore, this patient requires immediate fluid resuscitation for hemodynamic instability, making fluid resuscitation a higher priority than antibiotics alone.

D) INCORRECT:

High-dose loperamide is contraindicated in complicated diarrhea, especially in patients with fever and neutropenia. Antidiarrheal agents can worsen infectious complications and should not be used until serious infections are ruled out.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient has complicated cancer therapy-induced diarrhea with evidence of severe dehydration, acute kidney injury, and neutropenia with fever. The hemodynamic instability and organ dysfunction require immediate stabilization with IV fluids. The neutropenia with fever necessitates urgent blood cultures before antibiotic therapy, making fluid resuscitation and blood culture collection the highest priority interventions.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with acute myeloid leukemia presents to the emergency department with a 6-hour history of fever and malaise. He completed his first cycle of induction chemotherapy 8 days ago. Vital signs are BP, 92/65; P, 115; R, 20; T, 38.6°C (101.5°F). Physical examination shows mild oral mucositis but no other obvious source of infection. Laboratory studies show a WBC count of 600/μL with an absolute neutrophil count of 150 cells/μL. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Obtain blood cultures and urine culture before starting antibiotics
Start oral ciprofloxacin and amoxicillin/clavulanic acid
Perform chest x-ray and CT scan before treatment

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While blood cultures are important for guiding therapy, delaying antibiotic initiation in high-risk neutropenic fever significantly increases mortality. Cultures should be obtained at the same time as, not before, antibiotic administration.

B) INCORRECT:

While this patient has hypotension, starting vasopressors before adequate fluid resuscitation and antibiotic therapy is premature.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral antibiotics may be appropriate for low-risk patients (MASCC score ≥ 21) who are clinically stable. This patient has a MASCC score of 12, indicating high risk, and hypotension, which requires intravenous antibiotic therapy and inpatient management.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient has high-risk neutropenic fever (MASCC score < 21, profound neutropenia, hypotension, induction chemotherapy for acute myeloid leukemia, and advanced age). Empiric broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotics should be initiated immediately because neutropenic fever is an emergency with an increasing mortality risk if antibiotics are delayed beyond one hour. Blood cultures should be obtained but must not delay antibiotic initiation.

E) INCORRECT:

Additional imaging may help identify the source of infection, but it should not delay immediate antibiotic therapy in patients with neutropenic fever. The high mortality risk from delayed treatment in this emergency condition takes precedence over diagnostic workup.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents to the ED with intractable nausea and vomiting that began 6 hours after receiving moderately emetogenic chemotherapy. She received ondansetron and dexamethasone prophylaxis and has taken additional ondansetron at home without relief. She has vomited 8 times and is unable to keep fluids down. Physical exam reveals dry mucous membranes and poor skin turgor. In addition to IV fluid resuscitation, which of the following is the most appropriate antiemetic management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Continuing the current ondansetron dosing without modification will not address the breakthrough CINV. This patient has already failed standard prophylaxis and requires additional intervention.

B) INCORRECT:

Additional ondansetron may be chosen in some scenarios but another method is generally more effective.

C) INCORRECT:

Switching to promethazine only would replace rather than augment her current antiemetic therapy and is unlikely to be more effective.

D) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient has breakthrough CINV occurring despite standard prophylaxis with ondansetron and dexamethasone. The appropriate management is to add antiemetics of a different class.

E) INCORRECT:

Famotidine is an H2 receptor antagonist used for acid suppression and has no role in the management of CINV.
